{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Tommy Higginson | image = | caption = Higginson while with [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] in 1963. | fullname =Thomas Higginson<ref name="Timeless" /> | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1937|1|6}} | birth_place = [[Newtongrange]], Scotland | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|2012|7|22|1937|1|6}} | death_place = [[Isleworth]], England | height = | position = [[Left half]], [[inside forward]] | youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 = Edina Hibs | youthyears2 = | youthclubs2 = [[Penicuik Athletic F.C.|Penicuik Athletic]] | youthyears3 = 1956–1959 | youthclubs3 = [[Kilmarnock F.C.|Kilmarnock]] | years1 = 1959–1970 | clubs1 = [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] | caps1 = 387 | goals1 = 15 | years2 =1970–1973 | clubs2 = [[Hillingdon Borough F.C.|Hillingdon Borough]] | caps2 = | goals2 = }} '''Thomas "Tommy" Higginson''' (6 January 1937 – 22 July 2012) was a Scottish professional [[association football|football]] [[left half]] and [[inside forward]]. He is best remembered for his 12-year spell in the [[The Football League|Football League]] with [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]], for whom he made 433 appearances and is a member of the club's Hall of Fame.
== Club career ==
=== Kilmarnock === Higginson began his career with spells at junior clubs Edina Hibs and [[Penicuik Athletic F.C.|Penicuik Athletic.]]<ref name="Lane" /> In 1956, [[Kilmarnock F.C.|Kilmarnock]] manager [[Malky McDonald]] saw Higginson playing in a junior match and invited the youngster to a trial with the [[Scottish Football League]] club.<ref name="Lane">{{Cite book |title=Cult Bees & Legends: Volume One |last=Lane |first=David |publisher=Woodpecker Multimedia |year=2005 |isbn=0-9543682-0-7 |location=Hampton Wick |pages=110–117 }}</ref> He impressed enough to win a contract, but departed Killie in the summer of 1959 without making an appearance,<ref name="Lane" /> having missed two years due to his [[National Service in the United Kingdom|National Service]] and a ligament injury.<ref name="RIP" />
=== Brentford === Along with fellow [[Scotland|Scot]] [[John Docherty (footballer, born 1940)|John Docherty]], Higginson reunited with manager Malky McDonald at English [[Football League Division Three|Division Three]] side [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] in June 1959, as cover for [[Forward (association football)|forward]] [[Jim Towers]].<ref>{{Cite book|title = TW8 Matchday versus Oldham Athletic 25/08/03|last = |first = |publisher = The Yellow Printing Company Limited|year = |isbn = |location = London|pages = 32}}</ref> He began his time with the club in the [[Brentford F.C. Reserves and Academy#Reserve Team|reserve team]].<ref name="RIP">{{Cite web |url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2012/july/tommy-higginson-rip/ |title=Tommy Higginson RIP |date=23 July 2012 |publisher=Brentfordfc.co.uk |access-date=27 July 2014}}</ref> An [[inside forward]], Higginson made his debut in a league match versus [[Tranmere Rovers F.C.|Tranmere Rovers]] on 27 February 1960.<ref name="White" /> For the following game versus [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]], Higginson replaced club legend Jim Towers in the line-up and the [[Griffin Park]] support responded by booing manager Malky McDonald's decision.<ref name="Street">{{Cite web |url=http://www.getwestlondon.co.uk/sport/other-sport/tribute-former-brentford-legend-higginson-5974380 |title=Tribute to former Brentford legend Higginson |last=Street |first=Tim |date=5 August 2012 |publisher=Get West London |access-date=27 July 2014}}</ref> Despite this beginning, Higginson soon won over the Bees supporters with his performances.<ref name="Street" /> Moving back to a [[left half]] position, Higginson earned a reputation as a hard man after [[Rugby tackle|rugby tackling]] a [[Hartlepool United F.C.|Hartlepool United]] player during a 4–0 victory in October 1962, escaping with only [[Yellow card (football)|a booking]].<ref name="Street" />
Higginson was an ever-present in Brentford's [[1962–63 Brentford F.C. season|1962–63]] [[Football League Division Four|Division Four]] title-winning season.<ref name="White" /> In October 1964, Higginson suffered the ignominy of being the first Brentford player to be [[Red card (football)|sent off]] since the resumption of football after the [[Second World War]], receiving his marching orders (along with opposition player [[Eric Brodie]]) during a league match versus [[Shrewsbury Town F.C.|Shrewsbury Town]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Haynes |first=Graham |date=1998 |title=A-Z of Bees: Brentford Encyclopaedia |url= |location= |publisher=Yore Publications |isbn=1 874427 57 7 |accessdate= }}</ref> The [[News of the World Football Annual]] stated that Higginson once passed back to his own [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]] from a [[corner kick]].<ref>{{Cite book|title = News of the World Football Annual 1996–1997|last = Sewell|first = Albert|publisher = Invincible Press|year = 1996|isbn = 9780002187374|location = Hammersmith, London|page = 297}}</ref> In 1967 and with Brentford in a dire financial situation and the subject of a takeover bid by [[West London derby|rivals]] Queens Park Rangers, Higginson volunteered to take part in a Brentford to [[Brighton]] walk, to raise funds for the club.<ref name="Street" /> While many volunteers gave up, Higginson walked the whole way.<ref name="Street" /> Higginson remained with Brentford until the end of the [[1969-70 Football League Fourth Division|1969–70]] season and was awarded a [[Testimonial match|testimonial]] versus [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] in April 1969,<ref name="Timeless">{{Cite book |title=Timeless Bees: Brentford F.C. Who's Who 1920–2006 |last=Haynes |first=Graham |last2=Coumbe |first2=Frank |publisher=Yore Publications |year=2006 |isbn=978-0955294914 |location=Harefield |pages=139–140}}</ref> earning £1,853 from a 6,620 crowd.<ref>{{cite book |last= |first= |year=1996 |title=Griffin Gazette: Brentford's Official Matchday Magazine versus Crewe Alexandra 06/04/96 |url= |location= |publisher=Quay Design of Poole|page=20|isbn= |accessdate= }}</ref> He made 433 appearances for the Bees and is fifth on the club's record appearances list.<ref name="HallOfFame">{{Cite news |url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2016/december/tommy-higginson-inducted-into-hall-of-fame/ |title=Tommy Higginson inducted into the Brentford FC Hall of Fame |last=FC |first=Brentford |access-date=28 December 2016}}</ref> He was posthumously inducted into the Brentford [[List of Brentford F.C. Hall of Fame members|Hall of Fame]] in December 2016.<ref name="HallOfFame" />
=== Hillingdon Borough === Higginson saw out his career with [[Southern League Premier Division]] side [[Hillingdon Borough F.C.|Hillingdon Borough]],<ref name="bees">{{cite book |last= |first= |year=1999 |title=Official Matchday Magazine Of Brentford Football Club versus Oldham Athletic 14/08/99 |url= |location=Blackheath |page=41|publisher= Morganprint|isbn= |accessdate= }}</ref> reaching [[1970–71 FA Trophy|the final]] of the [[FA Trophy]] with the club in 1971.<ref name="Street" />
== Sunday League career == Higginson played on in [[Sunday league football]] during the 1970s, appearing for Thornbury, Syon Villa and [[Sutton Athletic F.C.|Sutton Athletic]].<ref name="Street" /> He retired from all football in 1990, at age 53.<ref name="Lane" />
== Personal life == Prior to becoming a footballer, Higginson was a champion youth boxer and athlete in Scotland, taking part in the Border Games and running professionally.<ref name="Lane" /><ref name="Street" /> While playing junior football, he also worked as a butcher.<ref name="Lane" /> While undertaking his National Service, Higginson saw active duty with the [[Royal Scots Regiment]] in [[Egypt]] during the [[Suez Crisis]].<ref name="Lane" /> While playing for Brentford, Higginson settled in [[Isleworth]]. After retiring from professional football in 1970, he worked for [[Firestone Tire and Rubber Company|Firestone]] for three years, before returning to his old job of butchering.<ref name="Lane" /> Higginson died at the age of 75 on 22 July 2012.<ref name="Street" /> He suffered with [[Alzheimer's disease]] in his later years. As a mark of respect, two days later the Brentford players wore [[Black armband#Mourning|black armbands]] during a [[pre-season friendly]] versus [[FC Erzgebirge Aue]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2012/july/mark-of-respect-for-higginson/ |title=Mark of Respect For Higginson |date=24 July 2012 |publisher=Brentfordfc.co.uk |access-date=27 July 2014}}</ref> Higginson's funeral was attended by many former Brentford favourites, including Peter Gelson, [[Alan Hawley (footballer)|Alan Hawley]] and [[Gordon Phillips (footballer)|Gordon Phillips]].<ref name="Street" />
== Honours ==
=== As a player === [[Brentford F.C.|'''Brentford''']] * [[Football League Division Four]]: [[1962–63 Brentford F.C. season|1962–63]]<ref name="White">{{Cite book|title=100 Years Of Brentford|last=|first=|publisher=Brentford FC|year=1989|isbn=0951526200|editor-last=White|editor-first=Eric|location=|pages=385–390|quote=|via=}}</ref>
=== As an individual === * [[List of Brentford F.C. Hall of Fame members|Brentford Hall of Fame]]<ref name="HallOfFame" />

[[File:William Stainton Moses Photograph.png|thumb|right|William Stainton Moses]] '''William Stainton Moses''' (1839–1892) was an [[England|English]] [[Clergy|cleric]] and spiritualist [[Mediumship|medium]]. ==Life== Moses was born in [[Donington, Lincolnshire|Donington]] near [[Lincoln, Lincolnshire|Lincoln]]. He was educated at [[Bedford School]], [[University College School|University College School, London]] and [[Exeter College, Oxford]].{{sfn|Rigg|1912}} He was ordained as a priest of the [[Church of England]] by [[Samuel Wilberforce|Bishop Samuel Wilberforce]] in 1870. Moses attended his first [[séance]] with Lottie Fowler in 1872. Charles Williams and [[Daniel Dunglas Home]] were the next mediums he visited. Five months after his introduction to [[spiritualism]], he claimed to have experienced [[levitation (paranormal)|levitation]]. The automatic scripts of Moses began to appear in his books ''Spirit Teachings'' and ''Spirit Identity''.{{sfn|Rigg|1912}} The scripts date from 1872 to 1883 and fill 24 notebooks. All but one have been preserved by the London Spiritualist Alliance. Moses published ''Psychography. A Treatise on One of the Objective Forms of Psychic or Spiritual Phenomena'' in 1878. In it, he coins the term "psychography" (from ''psycho'' and ''graphy'') for the spiritualist concept of channeling messages from the dead via [[automatic writing]] (also known as "independent writing", "direct writing" or "spirit writing"). Moses was one of the first vice-presidents of the [[Society for Psychical Research]] (SPR).[[Janet Oppenheim]]. (1988). ''The Other World: Spiritualism and Psychical Research in England, 1850-1914''. Cambridge University Press. p. 138. {{ISBN|978-0521347679}} "Moses became one of the first vice-presidents and council members of the SPR" Other early members included [[Frederic W. H. Myers]], [[Henry Sidgwick]] and [[Edmund Gurney]]. In 1886 and 1887 in a series of publications the SPR exposed the tricks of the medium [[William Eglinton]]. Because of this, some spiritualist members including Moses resigned from the SPR.[[Janet Oppenheim]]. (1988). ''The Other World: Spiritualism and Psychical Research in England, 1850-1914''. Cambridge University Press. pp. 139-140. {{ISBN|978-0521347679}} Moses endorsed the [[spirit photography]] of [[Édouard Isidore Buguet]], however, Buguet was exposed as a fraud.[[Joseph McCabe]]. (1920). ''Spiritualism: A Popular History From 1847''. Dodd, Mead and Company. pp. 151-173 Moses had supported Buguet in an article for ''Human Nature'' in May 1875.[[John Mulholland (magician)|John Mulholland]]. (1938). ''Beware Familiar Spirits''. C. Scribner's Sons. p. 150. {{ISBN|978-1111354879}} "Stainton Moses warmly endorsed Buguet in an article printed in May, 1875. In June, 1875, the French government arrested Buguet for fraud. At his trial he made a complete confession, and the police seized and produced his "spirit" doll and the collection of heads that fitted on it." After Burguet was exposed later in the same year, Moses insisted that Buguet was still a genuine medium and he had been bribed to make a false confession.[[Frank Podmore]]. (1902). ''Modern Spiritualism: A History and Criticism''. Volume 2. London: Methuen & Co. pp. 120-123.[[Simeon Edmunds]]. (1966). ''Spiritualism: A Critical Survey''. Aquarian Press. p. 115. "Stainton Moses even insisted that the prosecution was instigated by the Church, and that Buguet had been forced or bribed into making a false confession." The case has been cited by researchers as an example of spiritualists [[True-believer syndrome|willing to believe]] and refusing to accept evidence of fraud.[[Harry Houdini]]. (2011 edition). Originally published in 1924. ''A Magician Among the Spirits''. Cambridge University Press. pp. 120-124. {{ISBN|978-1-108-02748-9}}[[Ronald Pearsall]]. (1972). ''The Table-Rappers''. Book Club Associates. p. 124. {{ISBN|978-0750936842}}[[Milbourne Christopher]]. (1975). ''Mediums, Mystics & the Occult''. Thomas Y. Crowell. p. 114. {{ISBN|0-690-00476-1}} [[File:William Stainton Moses Photograph 2.png|thumb|left|Spirit photograph featuring Moses.]] In 1884, Moses was a founding member, together with Rogers, of the London Spiritualist Alliance, afterwards the [[College of Psychic Studies]].{{sfn|Rigg|1912}} Moses died on 5 September 1892.{{sfn|Rigg|1912}} ==Reception== Moses performed in dark conditions only with a small select circle of friends, he did not allow psychical researchers to attend his séances and refused to be tested.[[Hereward Carrington]]. (1907). ''The Physical Phenomena of Spiritualism''. Herbert B. Turner & Co. p. 14 The psychical researcher [[Frank Podmore]] wrote:
It seems reasonable to conclude that all the marvels reported at [Moses] seances were, in fact, produced by the medium's own hands: that it was he who tilted the table and produced the raps, that the scents, the seed pearls, and the Parian statuettes were brought into the room in his pockets: and that the spirit lights were, in fact, nothing more than bottles of phosphorised oil. Nor would the feats described have required any special skill on the medium's part.[[Frank Podmore]]. (1902). ''Modern Spiritualism: A History and a Criticism''. Volume 2. Methuen & Company. pp. 283-287
It was suggested that Moses looked up obituaries, daily newspapers, biographies or ''[[The Annual Register]]'' to research the history of deceased people. [[Joseph McCabe]] described Moses as a "deliberate impostor" and wrote that his [[Apport (paranormal)|apports]] and all of his feats were the result of trickery. Science historian [[Sherrie Lynne Lyons]] wrote that the glowing or light-emitting hands in séances could easily be explained by the rubbing of oil of [[phosphorus]] on the hands.[[Sherrie Lynne Lyons]]. (2010). ''Species, Serpents, Spirits, and Skulls: Science at the Margins in the Victorian Age''. State University of New York Press. p. 95. {{ISBN|978-1438427980}} Moses was caught twice with a bottle of phosphorus.[[Joseph McCabe]]. (1920). ''Is Spiritualism Based On Fraud? The Evidence Given By Sir A. C. Doyle and Others Drastically Examined''. London Watts & Co. p. 91 The psychologist [[Théodore Flournoy]] wrote that before admitting a supernatural explanation for the [[automatic writing]]s of Moses, "we must first of all be sure that he himself was not capable of elaborating them subconsciously. To my mind, he was quite capable."[[Théodore Flournoy]]. (1911). ''Spiritism and Psychology''. New York and London, Harper & Brothers. p. 142 Many of Moses's statements about ancient history have proven to be false.[[Joseph McCabe]]. (1920). ''Is Spiritualism Based On Fraud? The Evidence Given By Sir A. C. Doyle and Others Drastically Examined''. London Watts & Co. p. 186 Researcher [[Georgess McHargue]] has suggested that Moses' mediumship was the result of [[Autosuggestion|self-suggestion]] and unconscious trickery.[[Georgess McHargue]]. (1972). ''Facts, Frauds, and Phantasms: A Survey of the Spiritualist Movement''. Doubleday. p. 224. {{ISBN|978-0385053051}} The first documented instance of [[cryptomnesia]] occurred in 1874 with Moses.Brian Righi. (2008). ''Chapter 4: Talking Boards and Ghostly Goo''. In ''Ghosts, Apparitions and Poltergeists''. Llewellyn Publications. {{ISBN|978-0738713632}} "An early example of this occurred in 1874 with he medium William Stanton Moses, who communicated with the spirits of two brothers who had recently died in India. Upon investigation, it was discovered that one week prior to the séance, their obituary had appeared in the newspaper. This was of some importance because Moses's communications with the two spirits contained nothing that wasn't already printed in the newspaper."[[Robert Todd Carroll]]. (2014). [http://skepdic.com/cryptomn.html "Cryptomnesia"]. ''[[The Skeptic's Dictionary]]''.
